RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
TPL SouthTex Pipeline Company LLC
Silver Oak Gas Plant (Facility ID: 100000219131)

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

TPL SouthTex Pipeline Company LLC (Targa) owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, the Silver Oak Gas Plant, in Bee County, Texas.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid products from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means.  Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.
The Silver Oak Plant has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Silver Oak Gas Plant is located approximately 3 miles east of Mineral, Texas, on County Road 107. Targa operates the process to produce the following petroleum products:

1. Y grade mixture from natural gas
2. Condensate
3. Residue Gas

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS (OCA) RESULTS

Targa treats the entire gas plant as one process.  Several vessels at the gas plant were evaluated for offsite consequence analyses.  There are three worst-case scenarios (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at Silver Oak Gas Plant.  The first involves 292,200 pounds (60,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in one of two interconnected natural gas liquid storage tanks. The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resultin

g in a vapor cloud explosion and impacting an area with a 0.5 mile radius. The second scenario involves one set of condensate inlet slug catcher tubes and results in a vapor cloud explosion of 296,413 pounds (62,200 gallons) of flammable mixture. The third scenario involves the natural gas liquids surge tank at Plant 2 and results in a vapor cloud explosion of 309,245 pounds (63,500 gallons) of flammable mixture.  The second and third scenarios also impact a 0.5 mile radius; however, different off-site receptors are impacted in each scenario. Therefore, all three scenarios are included in this plan. 

Since the facility is located in a populated area, each WCS could affect offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.  Targa has numerous controls to prevent such a release and to manage one's consequences. Passive mitigation measures include an automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and actuated valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare. 

The alternative release scenario (ARS) for the flammable substances at Silver Oak Gas Plant is assumed to be the release of 37,499 pounds (7,700 gallons) of the flammable mixture from the natural gas liquid pump moving product to the pipeline exiting the plant. This creates a vapor cloud explosion with a 0.3 mile radius. The release is expected to be isolated by plant operation personnel within 10 minutes, to manually shut down the pump from the control room. 

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Silver Oak Gas Plant is covered by the OSHA PSM Program to aid in accident release prevention. 

A. Employee Participation

Targa encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as follows:

1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information
2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP
3. Maintaining good engineering practices
4. Participating as a m

ember of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team

Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.

B. Process Safety Information

Targa's Silver Oak Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These technical documents address the following:

1. Chemical properties and associated hazards
2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3. Maximum intended inventories
4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment
5. Equipment design basis and configuration information
6. Identification of all necessary regulatory equipment design documents
7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices

The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM Program.

Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in material safety data sheet (MSDS).  For specific areas within the process, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator's procedures manual.  The facility maintains the overall process within these limits by using controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems. 

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings.  This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed facility changes to safety features are not compromised. 

C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

The Silver Oak Plant has a comprehensive program to identif

y and control hazard associated with the RMP covered scenario.  This program systematically examines and explores for potential hazards, then establishes controls to put in place to manage the potential hazards.  The PHA is conducted using checklists with a team consisting of Targa employees who have operation, maintenance, engineering and safety experience.  The team identifies, evaluates, and makes recommendations to management of potential hazards identified.  The team's findings are forwarded to Targa and Silver Oak Management for resolution.  The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the scenario is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

D. Operating Procedures

Targa's Silver Oak Gas Plant maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee suggestion, compliance audit, PHA, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.

Covered Process Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process is operating within its safe limits.

E.  Training

The Silver Oak Gas Plant has

implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process.  New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn specific duties and tasks.  A performance review and written test or hands-on observation specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request.  All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

F. Contractors

The Silver Oak Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near Covered Process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:

1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills
3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work

This is accomplished by providing contractors with:

1. A process overview
2. Information about safety and health hazards
3. Emergency response plan requirements
4. Safe work practices before beginning work

In addition, Silver Oak Gas Plant Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance

during the selection of a contractor.  Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations. 

G. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

Targa's Silver Oak Gas Plant conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment in service.  This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involved field verification of the construction serves as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

H. Mechanical Integrity

The Silver Oak Gas Plant has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment.  The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:

1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures

In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on:

1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures
4. Emergency response plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.

Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is correct

ed before placing the equipment back into service.  A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.

An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The Silver Oak Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

I. Safe Work Practices

The Silver Oak Gas Plant as long-standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, Industrial Standards and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.

J. Management of Change

The Silver Oak Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all Reported Covered Scenarios.  This system requires that changes to items such as equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to:

1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards
2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.

K. Incident Investigation

The Silver Oak Gas Plant promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered scenario that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.  Co

rrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are traced until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years. 

L. Compliance Audits

At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing all OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of Silver Oak Gas Plant.  This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  

M. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The following is a description of existing features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.

Universal Prevention Activities

The Silver Oak Gas Plant accident release prevention and response policies are applied to the RMP covered process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and human errors.

N. Specialized Safety Features

Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:

1. Contain/control a release
2. Quickly detect a release, and
3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release

The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

O. Release Detection

1. Facility walk-through once per shift
2. Alarms to signal process upsets

P. Release Containment/Control

1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases. 
2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically opera

te all automatic valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.
4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases
5. Atmospheric relief devices

Q. Release Mitigation

1. Fire extinguishers
2. Trained emergency response personnel
3. Personal protective equipment
4. Blast resistant building to help protect control systems and personnel

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Silver Oak Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention since start-up in 2012.  There have been no accidental releases from the covered process that resulted in death, injury or significant property damage on site, or known off site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage during this period.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Targa's Silver Oak Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of Targa staff, local emergency response agencies, and the public if a release occurs. However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the facility would rely on the local fire department to respond.  

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.  The Silver Oak Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

There are currently no planned changes to improve safety. Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued to improvement to the level of safety at the Silver Oak Gas Plant. Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:

The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

The PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards. 

The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety pr

ogram.

Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
